content: The National Center for Transportation Solutions Act of 2004 establishes the Center and outlines its duties, organization, powers, and personnel matters. It also includes provisions for a National Transportation Research Director, a Board, and Regional centers. Authorization of appropriations is also addressed. Congress finds that research and development are crucial for a transportation system that meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, efficiency, equity, and environmental protection goals. Despite a 40% increase in overall transportation funding, resources for transportation research and development have remained stagnant. There is a need for more funding and focus on long-term transportation goals through competitive, peer-reviewed research awards. The diversity of research programs addressing various customer needs presents challenges. The competitive award of research funding is crucial for addressing long-term transportation needs. The diversity of research programs poses challenges, making priority setting difficult. To ensure the transportation system meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, and environmental protection goals, increasing federal investment in long-range planning and supporting peer-reviewed research is essential. The curr_chunk focuses on improving transportation planning by supporting competitive research, coordinating research programs, exchanging data, and setting nationwide priorities in federal transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is established as an independent agency in the executive branch of government. It consists of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board and the Director of National Transportation Research. The Board will exercise the authorities of the Center. The National Center for Transportation Solutions focuses on promoting research and development in multimodal transportation through long-term policies and projects with public benefits. It awards grants to support strategic transportation objectives and facilitates data interchange among interested parties in the United States. The National Center for Transportation Solutions facilitates data interchange among transportation research parties in the US, evaluates government research programs, and submits annual reports to Congress on its activities. The National Center for Transportation Solutions submits an annual report to Congress on its activities, including recommendations for research and development in multimodal transportation. The National Center for Transportation Solutions submits an annual report to Congress on its activities, including recommendations for research and development in multimodal transportation. SEC. 5 establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established with 16 voting members appointed by various authorities to represent different professions and sectors. The Board members must represent various professions and regions, possess relevant skills, and serve for 6-year terms with a limit of two consecutive terms. Initial appointments should be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with staggered terms for the members. The Board members' terms are staggered, with six members serving for six years, five for four years, and five for two years. Terms do not expire during election years, and vacancies do not affect the Board. The Board members' terms are staggered, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board shall hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, with meetings called by the Chair. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Board selects a Chairman and Vice Chairman for 2-year terms, with a limit of two consecutive terms as Chairman. The Director of National Transportation Research is appointed by the President with Senate consent, serves as the chief executive of the Center, and is a nonvoting member of the Board. The Director's term is six years, and their salary is capped at the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Center's organization is outlined in Section 7. The Center is organized into divisions including Transportation Safety, Environmental Planning, Infrastructure, Intermodal Connections, and Transportation Economics. Each division has a committee composed of at least five members serving two-year terms, with an annual Chairman election. Each division committee within the Center shall have at least five members serving two-year terms. The committee shall elect a Chairman annually and establish its own procedures within the guidelines set by the Board. The Center's division committees have at least five members serving two-year terms, electing a Chairman annually and establishing their own procedures within Board guidelines. The Center has powers outlined in Section 8. The Board and division committees have the authority to hold hearings, gather information from Federal agencies, enter into contracts, and use postal services to carry out the purposes of the Act. Additionally, the Board can enter into sole source agreements with entities like the National Academy of Sciences for studies to develop policies and strategies. The Board and division committees can use postal services and accept gifts. The Center can publish research results. SEC. 9. CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Director of the Center may appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. The staff is responsible for creating strategic and annual plans, developing budgets, administering programs, providing support to the Board, and coordinating with other departments. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and dismiss staff without following civil service laws. Staff duties include creating plans, developing budgets, administering programs, supporting the Board, and collaborating with other departments. The Director must report progress to the Board periodically and coordinate with various organizations to leverage resources. The Director can set compensation for personnel without following certain pay regulations, and government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement. The Director of the Center can appoint and dismiss staff without following civil service laws. Government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. Volunteer services can also be accepted without certain restrictions. SEC. 10. REGIONAL CENTERS FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS. The Director will award grants to establish regional centers for transportation solutions in four regions of the United States. These centers will conduct research on long-term multimodal transportation issues with clear public benefits and where private investment is necessary. The northeast regional center will be located in one of the five states with the highest traffic congestion levels in the country. States must be located in one of the 5 States with the highest traffic congestion levels in the US based on vehicle miles traveled on National Highway System roads and one of the 10 States with the highest congestion levels in urban areas. Authorization of appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006 to 2010: $50,000,000 in 2006, $100,000,000 in 2007, $150,000,000 in 2008, $200,000,000 in 2009, and $250,000,000 in 2010.
